thread.title: White House tour: Surprising things I saw inside President Obama’s house
thread.title_full: White House tour: Surprising things I saw inside President Obama’s house

author: ROSCOE WHALAN
title: White House tour: Surprising things I saw inside President Obama’s house
text:
INVITATIONS to the White House don’t come around too often; you have to either be very important, be receiving commendation on some achievement — or if you’re lucky like me, your Australian press credentials are vague and unassuming enough to get you inside.
Today, I stepped onto the grounds of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington D.C., the most famous address in America and probably the most secure.
While I’d studied up on what to expect (read: watched House of Cards in one sitting over the course of a weekend), the President’s home was still full of surprises:
ENTERING THE GROUNDS
Airports eat your heart out. Three-plus security checkpoints later I was herded into a holding pen with the rest of the media. Much like the first day of high school you can pick the new kids on the block. While the veterans read newspapers on deck chairs they’d brought from home, the newbies were too scared to take photos at risk of causing a security breach.
SECURITY
Speaking of security, Secret Service Officers are everywhere. You know how I knew that they were secret? Their uniforms are emblazoned with the words, “Secret Service”, which seems a little counterintuitive to me. However, they are heavy armed. What kind of weaponry, you ask? No idea. Unlike their uniforms, they didn’t have names written on them.
PRESS BRIEFING ROOM
The hallowed grounds of the likes of Mike McLintock and C.J. Cregg, the Press Briefing Room is where a lot of important people ask questions about very important things. I was neither of those things. Under the dozens of LED lights that lit up the semi-submerged room, journalists buzzed about making phone calls, others furiously filed stories in crammed quarters and cameramen repeatedly conducted audio and visual checks — ready for a press conference that wasn’t scheduled for at least a couple of hours.
It looks much bigger on TV. Source: Supplied
Josh Earnest is currently the White House Press Secretary. Source: Supplied
THE GRAND ENTRANCE
Like a call to the principal’s office, the anticipation builds as we’re given a 10-minute warning to assemble. Ushered from the depths of the Press Briefing Room, we entered through the north portico, aka the front door. Unfortunately, Michelle and Barack weren’t there welcome us — neither did Bo and Sunny come bounding to the door.
SWEET TUNES
Instead, as the doors to the Entrance Hall opened up, the sweet sounds of the US Marine Band tickled my ears. Just a handful of the team known as “The President’s Own” were on hand. I’m not sure what was more impressive; their immaculately pressed uniforms or the guitarist slapping the bass — the tunes were classic and they didn’t take requests.
THE GRAND FOYER
I walked across the marble floors where John Travolta and Lady Diana once famously waltzed. I wasn’t as light on my feet though, as I was distracted by the portraits of former Presidents that adorned the walls of the Grand Staircase that led up to the Obama’s private quarters.
NO FREE WI-FI
The United States may be leaders of the free world but forget about logging onto the President’s network.
THE EAST ROOM
It’s no West Wing but the East Room in The White House plays host the most. In many respects, it’s just a big rectangular room, which makes it perfectly versatile for events ranging from policy announcements to performances from Stevie Wonder. Today, it was welcoming WNBA Champions the Phoenix Mercury.
Waiting for the Big-O. Source: Supplied
It’s a full house. Source: Supplied
COMMANDER-IN-CHIEF SWAG
What’s more impressive than Barack Obama? Barack Obama chilling in his own home. After a long build up, the loudspeaker bellowed, “Ladies and Gentleman, The President of the United States of America!” On cue, POTUS bounded out from backstage, pointing and laughing with the crowd that would’ve clapped louder if they weren’t so busy fumbling around for their phones to take the perfect Instagram shot.
#Obama #WhiteHouse #Where’sthefreewifiObama? Source: Supplied
THAT’S A LOT OF GRASS
From afar The White House may look tiny but that’s really because it’s in the middle of 18 acres of land. It takes 13 green thumbs to keep the garden looking tiptop. It appears they take their jobs very seriously — one of the groundskeepers was dismayed that her lawn mowing was put on hold when our festivities moved outside.
PATIENCE IS A VIRTUE
In total, I was on The White House grounds for more than three hours. The official proceedings lasted 10 minutes.
